0: Students at Norman High School walk out of classes in Norman, Oklahoma November 24, 2014 to protest what they said was a failure by school administrators to take care of three girls who have accused a male classmate of sexually assaulting them. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Students at Norman High School walk out of classes in Norman, Oklahoma November 24, 2014 to protest what they said was a failure by school administrators to take care of three girls who have accused a male classmate of sexually assaulting them. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NORMAN, Okla. Hundreds of students at an Oklahoma high school walked out of classes on Monday to protest what they said was a failure by school administrators to take care of three girls who have accused a male classmate of sexually assaulting them. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The girls have all stopped attending Norman High School due to what they say is bullying by friends of the alleged assailant, who was suspended after he was suspected of posting a video of one of the sexual encounters online. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I hope it stops," said Rachel Capshaw, a ninth grader at the school. "Public schools should be a safe place." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The protest at the Norman school comes after several major U.S. colleges, including the University of Virginia, began investigating high profile accusations of sexual assault on their campuses. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In September, a female student in at the Norman school accused another student of rape, spurring at least two other girls to accuse the same male student of sexually assaulting them. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR One of the girls said that on the day she came back to school after the alleged rape, she was verbally assaulted by a group of students who bullied her about the incident. She has not returned to the school after that. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A spokeswoman for Norman Public Schools said as soon the school system became aware of the rape accusations, it acted swiftly. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The idea that we would punish a victim for being a victim is reprehensible," said Shelly Hickman, communications director for Norman Public Schools. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR She said the district has been working with police. Norman police said the case is being investigated and offered no further details.
